title: New Citi-Commissioned EIU Report Projects Competitiveness of 120 of the World's Major Cities In 2025
summary: Singapore - A new Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) research report, "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities," commissioned by Citi, reveals that Singapore has retained the top spot as the most competitive city in Asia and the third most competitive city globally. Released yesterday at the New Cities Summit in São Paulo, the report forecasts the competitiveness of 120 cities in 2025 based on their projected ability to attract capital, business, talent and tourists.
tag-1: New Citi-Commissioned EIU Report Projects Competitiveness of 120 of the World's Major Cities In 2025
tag-3: Singapore – A new Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) research report, "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities," commissioned by Citi, reveals that Singapore has retained the top spot as the most competitive city in Asia and the third most competitive city globally. Released yesterday at the New Cities Summit in São Paulo, the report forecasts the competitiveness of 120 cities in 2025 based on their projected ability to attract capital, business, talent and tourists.
tag-4: According to the report, the 10 most competitive cities in the world in 2025 are forecast to be New York (1st), London (2nd), Singapore (3rd), Hong Kong (4th), Tokyo (5th), Sydney (6th), Paris (7th), Stockholm (8th), Chicago (9th) and Toronto (10th). The report also reveals that São Paulo, Incheon and Mumbai will surge in global competitiveness between 2012 and 2025.
tag-5: Citi commissioned the "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities" Index to improve understanding of market competitiveness and to identify where growth, opportunity and talent are likely to be found in the decades ahead. Citi recognizes that competitiveness is about more than growth – especially as urban centers vie for investment, talent and business. The report builds on the inaugural EIU report "Hot Spots: Benchmarking Global City Competitiveness," commissioned by Citi in 2012.
tag-6: "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities" projects cities' competitive standing in 2025 across eight distinct categories of competitiveness and 32 individual indicators. Categories include economic strength, physical capital, financial maturity, institutional character, human capital, global appeal, social and cultural character, and environmental and natural hazards. A city's overall ranking in the Index is a weighted score of the underlying categories. The report builds on the inaugural EIU report, "Hot Spots: Benchmarking Global City Competitiveness," commissioned by Citi in 2012.
tag-7: Asia Cities: A source of growth and a magnet of opportunity for businesses and people
tag-8: The 10 most competitive cities in Asia in 2025 are forecasted to be Singapore (1st), Hong Kong (2nd), Tokyo (3rd), Sydney (4th), Taipei (5th), Seoul (6th), Melbourne (7th), Kuala Lumpur (8th), Shanghai (9th) and Auckland (10th).
tag-42: Physical infrastructure, financial maturity and global appeal are driving the competiveness of Asia's cities on an international scale – especially for Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo. These cities are a source of growth and a magnet of opportunity for businesses and people alike in Asia.
tag-43: "More than half of the world's population lives in cities, a trend that will only continue as nearly 60 million people migrate to urban centers each year," said Stephen Bird, Citi CEO for Asia Pacific. "Cities are the engines of global growth, and Citi is committed to helping them compete on the global stage by transforming the ways in which urban centers develop and operate. The findings of this report indicate that the economic rise of Asian cities will be mirrored by the region's increased competitiveness in 2025. The region's cities will also continue to make gains in the quality of its infrastructure, effectiveness of its institutions, investment in human capital and growing global appeal, making them a magnet for businesses and visitors in the years to come. In many of these markets, Citi is partnering with governments and clients to further enable urban progress."
tag-44: "Asia's growth and global preeminence are reflected in the development and competitiveness of its urban centers," said Leo Abruzzese, the EIU's global forecasting director. "The growth in competitiveness of large and mid-sized cities proves Asia's diverse urban development."
tag-46: Singapore ranks third overall in the Index and is the highest-placed Asian city. It came in joint first overall in terms of its physical capital, financial maturity, and environment and natural hazard. In terms of global appeal, it came in third overall. The report states that Singapore's strong showing in these categories is not surprising given the city's efficient transport system, lean bureaucracy, safe and clean environment, and increasingly high international reputation.
tag-47: Mr. Michael Zink, Head of ASEAN and Citi Country Officer for Singapore, said: "As a company with a 111 year history in Singapore, Citi is uniquely positioned to be the catalyst and enabler of progress through our innovative financial tools, efficient payments and collections platforms, and expert financial advice. To help Singapore sustain its economic growth and preserve its future competitiveness, Citi is partnering with private and public sector organizations to help modernize the city's infrastructure, create jobs and enhance liveability. Through its efforts, Citi is committed to supporting Singapore's continued development and maintaining its competitive edge among cities of the world."
tag-48: In Singapore, Citi has been working closely with a number of sectors, including the education and healthcare industries, to facilitate progress.
tag-49: Citi has a rich history of working with the education sector in Singapore, particularly with higher education institutions to provide financial solutions via Citi's innovative financial platforms to enhance their efficiencies. These solutions span from bursary disbursements for exchange students travelling overseas to per-diem payments for visiting researchers. Citi's global footprint and services gives education providers complete visibility and management of their cash across domestic and offshore campuses using a single platform.
tag-50: Citi has also been actively engaged with key players in Singapore's healthcare ecosystem. Singapore has an integrated healthcare system that provides a care-continuum which covers primary, acute and step-down providers. Citi's innovative financial solutions are used by hospitals and health authorities in Singapore to enhance patient service deliveries and outcomes. These include card solutions that streamline procurement processes, and drive health incentive programs and cash management services, enabling operational efficiencies.
tag-51: One of Citi's key business strategies under the Citi for Cities initiative is to enable cities to become more efficient and competitive.
tag-52: For 200 years, Citi's central mission has been to enable economic progress. With its global footprint, Citi connects clients to the world, working at the center of global trade and capital flows. On the ground in more than 1,000 cities, Citi has a unique perspective on the complexities of the urban environment. Through Citi for Cities and other initiatives, Citi works with clients and public and private sector partners in cities around the world to enhance public services, facilitate commerce, expand financial inclusion and harness advancements in digital, mobile and card technologies.
tag-54: São Paulo, Incheon and Mumbai are top movers between 2012 and 2025. Brazil's commercial and financial capital, São Paulo (36th), is the most improved city in the Index. Its coming surge in competitiveness can be attributed to the city's young and rapidly growing workforce, solid telecommunications infrastructure, well-established democratic institutions and financial maturity.
tag-55: Incheon (43rd), South Korea's third largest city, is the second-biggest mover. Investments in a world class port, transportation infrastructure and the development of the Incheon Free Economic Zone have all resulted in the city becoming a commercial, business, logistics and tourism hub for all of northeast Asia, with more progress to come. Incheon's rise in the overall rankings demonstrates the institutional, social and economic progress that many cities in emerging Asia have made in the last few decades. It also signals the growing competitiveness of emerging market cities that will be seen by 2025 and beyond.
tag-56: India's financial capital, Mumbai (51st), comes in third in terms of improved competitiveness. This boost is driven by its sheer economic strength, improved financial maturity, and cultural vibrancy.
tag-57: New York continues its reign as the world's most competitive city. According to the forecast, New York is the most competitive city today and will remain so through 2025. It tops the rankings in terms of financial maturity and is among the most competitive in institutional character and economic strength.
tag-58: North American and Western European cities retain their competitive edge. Cities in the United States and Western Europe will continue to attract capital, businesses, tourists and talent, despite concerns over aging populations, infrastructure and lingering impacts of the financial crisis. However, the Eurozone crisis will impact cities in Southern and Eastern Europe, creating a 'competitiveness divide' in the region. For example, Madrid (joint 46th), Rome (68th), and Bucharest (80th) all fall in the rankings from 2012 to 2025.
tag-59: China's rate of competitiveness eases. No Chinese city is ranked among the top-25 most improved. This is due to the progress that many Chinese cities made during the first decade of this century. By 2025, China will have surpassed the United States as the world's largest economy, thanks to strong growth, rapid urbanization and rising productivity.
